summaries.body: The Twitter account of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin sent word that he was seeking the 2016 Republican nomination for president — perhaps inadvertently, perhaps not.
McDonald's denied accusations that its Happy Meal toys from the animated film "Minions" use foul language and said there were no plans to pull them from distribution.
Mike Moustakas of the Kansas City Royals and Carlos Martinez of the St. Louis Cardinals won the final fan votes and will go to the All-Star Game.
Yanis Varoufakis, the former Greek finance minister, wrote in an op-ed that creditors have refused to offer essential debt relief because of politics, not economics.
Dalvin Cook, a sophomore starting running back for Florida State, was charged with misdemeanor battery and suspended from the football team.
Characters on "The Simpsons" are often seen guzzling Duff Beer. Now 21st Century Fox, the media company, will sell a real-life version of the brew, starting in Chile.
The N.F.L. reduced its suspension for Greg Hardy, a Dallas Cowboys defensive end, from 10 games to four. He was suspended for his involvement in a domestic violence case.
LeBron James signed a one-year contract with the Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday. The deal has a player option for the 2016-17 season.
The presidents of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone appealed for $3.2 billion to help the Ebola-hit countries recover from the epidemic.
The defense rested its case in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a Colorado theater in 2012. Closing arguments are set to begin Tuesday.
Farid Fata, a Michigan doctor, was sentenced to 45 years in prison for a Medicare fraud scheme that involved giving chemotherapy to patients who did not have cancer.
General Motors said it was recalling nearly 780,000 crossover SUVs, mainly in North America, because their rear power lift gates could fall and hit people.
Japan’s new satellite captures an image every 10 minutes, painting a living portrait of Earth. On its first official day, the weather systems shown include typhoons spinning in the western Pacific.
McDonald's said it had no plans to stop distributing a talking Happy Meal toy inspired by the movie "Minions," even though some customers said it sounds as if it is cursing.

display_asset.caption: Novak Djokovic celebrated his victory over Richard Gasquet in a Wimbledon men's semifinal on Friday.

summaries.body: Novak Djokovic, above, defeated Richard Gasquet, 7-6 (2), 6-4, 6-4, to advance to his fourth Wimbledon final.
An appeals court upheld the conviction of Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia, who was convicted last year of bribery and corruption.
Tunisia's Interior Ministry said security forces had killed five suspected extremists. The operation came after a gunman killed 38 tourists at a resort in June.
The police detained one of China’s most prominent human rights lawyers in Beijing, after an additional three rights lawyers disappeared in the capital within 24 hours.

display_asset.credit: Newsha Tavakolian/Magnum, for The New York Times

summaries.body: Thousands of people chanted "Down with America" and "Death to Israel" in annual rallies in Iran, as Iran and six nations held talks in Vienna on its nuclear program.
China's military will prosecute another former senior officer for corruption, the Defense Ministry said, part of a campaign that has already targeted dozens of top people.
Pilots flew two electric planes, one made by Airbus, across the English Channel for the first time, journeys seen as a step toward making such flights viable in the long term.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent on a meeting between top European officials to discuss the Greek debt crisis, via Twitter

summaries.body: Teleconference at 1pm between @JunckerEU, @Lagarde, @J_Dijsselbloem and Draghi on Greece proposal. @tsipras_eu #eurogroup
German police arrested a man in Bavaria suspected of shooting dead a woman from his Mercedes convertible, and then fatally shooting a cyclist.
Tunisia's prime minister said his country did "everything in our power" to protect tourists, after Britain said another attack was likely and urged its citizens to leave.
Citing concerns about music rights, the BBC has halted playing anything by Neil Young, the Doors, Journey or Bonnie Raitt — or even songs that sample their work.
Trying to address a housing shortage, Britain will announce new rules that include automatic approval for developments on land once used for industrial purposes.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse, via The Straits Times

summaries.body: Rainfall last month appears to have "considerably eased" North Korea's drought, but key rice-producing areas are still afflicted, South Korea's Unification Ministry said.

posts.footer: The Times's Tehran bureau chief, covering annual protests against Israel and other perceived enemies of Iran, via Twitter

summaries.body: A group of kids carrying a banner saying: "resistance until victory." http://t.co/uISpT59z6V
United Airlines is investigating an incident in June in which a pilot dumped live ammunition down a toilet during a flight to Munich from Houston.

posts.footer: Panupong Sritananuwat, one of 14 Thai students recently jailed for protesting military rule, who said security personnel had shadowed them since their release this week, via The Nation

summaries.body: We are not criminals. They don't really need to follow us like this. I feel very unsafe indeed.
A North Korean pesticide factory recently visited by Kim Jong-un could be used to make "military-size batches of anthrax," the website 38 North reported.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse, via The Straits Times

summaries.body: At least 17 people were killed in a stampede at a Bangladeshi factory compound where free clothes were being given away, the police said.
McDonald's denied that a talking "Minions" toy included in Happy Meals uses curse words, though "a very small number of customers" have complained that it does.
Indonesia closed five airports due to ash from a volcanic eruption. Thousands of travelers were stranded in Bali.

display_asset.caption: George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, at the ceremony for graduates of the Presidential Leadership Scholars program, held Thursday at the George W. Bush Presidential Center in Dallas.
display_asset.credit: Cooper neill for The New York Times

summaries.body: In a rare joint appearance, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton were all charm as they took the stage in Dallas to promote a scholarship program.
Irwin Keyes, a character actor who played Hugo the bodyguard on "The Jeffersons" and had a long career portraying villains and henchmen, has died at 63.
The lion population has grown at Mozambique's biggest game reserve, partly because the lions are feeding on elephants killed by poachers, a conservationist said.

display_asset.caption: New York City Police Sgt. Joseph Freer demonstrates one of the body cameras being tested by the Police Department.

summaries.body: A federal monitor recommended a larger trial program for body cameras on New York police officers.
In recent weeks, Facebook has held preliminary discussions with the major record companies, seeking licensing deals to insert music videos into Facebook users’ feeds.
The U.N. human rights chief warned that an explosion of violence is close at hand in Burundi, where political protests have been met by a security crackdown.

display_asset.caption: Geoffrey Zakarian
display_asset.credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times..Published 09-03-2014

summaries.body: Geoffrey Zakarian, a high-profile chef, dropped out of Donald Trump’s forthcoming luxury hotel in Washington after his remarks about Mexican immigrants.
The F.D.A. is strengthening its warning labels for pain relievers like ibuprofen, adding information about the risk of heart attack and stroke.
Ken Stabler, an M.V.P. for the Oakland Raiders and a star quarterback at the University of Alabama, died on Wednesday, his family said. He was 69.
Shepard Fairey, a street artist and creator of the Barack Obama "Hope" poster, was arrested in Los Angeles. He was wanted in Detroit for property crimes.
Tom Selleck, the actor, reached a tentative settlement with a water district over allegations that he stole truckloads of water from a hydrant in drought-racked California.
The N.C.A.A. lifted a 14-year ban on holding championship events in South Carolina after the governor signed a law to remove the Confederate flag from the Capitol.
Two new cases of Ebola were reported in Liberia in the same community where the virus recently resurged, officials said. There are now five confirmed cases.
Wisconsin lawmakers passed a ban on abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy. The bill heads to Gov. Scott Walker.
The F.B.I. director said the authorities thwarted plots to kill people in the U.S. around July 4 and in recent weeks arrested more than 10 people inspired by the Islamic State.
Ray McDonald, a former N.F.L. player, was charged with felony domestic violence after what the police said was a clash with his ex-fiancée and their infant child in May.
The Saudi-backed government of Yemen agreed to a “pause” in fighting, starting Friday, so that humanitarian relief can be delivered, a U.N. spokesman said.
The New York Times's Jim Yardley answered questions from readers about his travels with Pope Francis in Ecuador, Bolivia and Paraguay.

display_asset.caption: A Domino's Pizza in Brooklyn. The pizza industry had campaigned against a F.D.A. rule requiring the posting of calorie counts on menus.
display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: The Food and Drug Administration pushed back the deadline for chain restaurants, pizza parlors and movie theaters to post calorie counts on their menus to December 2016.
Most of Florida's congressional districts will have to be redrawn before next year's elections after a ruling from the state's highest court.
The Italian oil field contractor Saipem said Gazprom, the Russian gas exporter, had canceled its contract to build a natural gas pipeline under the Black Sea.
New studies say rats and monkeys whose brains are linked by electrodes can coordinate their brains to carry out tasks, often better than individuals do.
The number of people who applied for U.S. jobless benefits last week jumped to 297,000, the highest level since February, mainly because of shutdowns at auto plants.
The consumer products giant Procter & Gamble has agreed to sell its portfolio of 43 beauty brands to the beauty products maker Coty for $12.5 billion, the companies said.

display_asset.caption: Fireflies near Wuhan, Hubei Province. On Thursday, Shanghai's first firefly exhibit canceled its opening over safety issues.

summaries.body: A program inviting Chinese city dwellers to visit an enclosure in Shanghai with thousands of fireflies inside was suspended over fears of ecological damage and safety concerns.
Dragan Vasiljkovic, a Serbian ex-commander accused of war crimes in Croatia in the 1990s, arrived in Zagreb to face trial after failing to stop his extradition from Australia.
European antitrust officials filed formal charges against MasterCard, accusing the company of setting artificially high fees for credit card transactions in the European Union.
India's top court ordered an inquiry into a multimillion-dollar college admission and government job recruitment scandal said to be linked to dozens of mysterious deaths.
London Tube employees are on strike, forcing the first total shutdown of the rail network in 13 years and causing chaos for commuters across the city.
The Nigerian military said it had arrested a suspect who is believed to have planned Boko Haram attacks in the cities of Jos and Zaria that killed more than 70 people.
North Korea has carried out 70 executions since Kim Jong-un took power in 2011, South Korea's foreign minister said. He did not say where he had gotten the information.
Over four million Syrians have fled the war-ravaged country, the U.N. said. A senior official called it "the biggest refugee population from a single conflict in a generation."
Thailand confirmed that it had sent ethnic Uighurs back to China, despite concerns for their safety. Earlier in Istanbul, protesters stormed the Thai consulate over the news.

display_asset.caption: DeAndre Jordan, center, in April. He led the league in rebounding (15 per game) and field-goal percentage (71 percent) last season.

summaries.body: DeAndre Jordan re-signed with the Los Angeles Clippers, reneging on an oral commitment to Dallas and ending nearly 12 hours of suspense and ridiculousness.
A fashion blogger who claimed to be a stylist for Johnny Depp and others, and who bought expensive clothes in Manhattan purportedly on their behalf, avoided prison with a plea deal.

display_asset.caption: The recall affects 165,000 Hummer H3s and H3Ts in the United States.

summaries.body: General Motors is recalling nearly 200,000 Hummers because of an electrical problem that could cause a fire inside the dashboard, the automaker said.

posts.footer: Daniel Toole, East Asia regional director for Unicef, calling for action to protect malnourished children in North Korea, which is in the midst of a severe drought, via Agence France-Presse

summaries.body: If we delay until we are certain of crop failures, it may well be too late to save the most vulnerable children.
A federal judge in Minneapolis ordered three young men accused of plotting to travel to Syria to fight for ISIS kept in detention while awaiting trial, at least for now.
A psychiatrist testifying for the defense in James E. Holmes’s trial said that Mr. Holmes was schizophrenic when he opened fire in a Colorado theater, killing 12 people.

posts.footer: A Bloomberg News journalist in Hong Kong, via Twitter

summaries.body: Shanghai Composite erases losses, jumps 2.3%. 50% of China's stock market still suspended. Hong Kong stocks rebound 4.1%
A New Zealand court sentenced AC/DC's former drummer Phil Rudd to eight months of home detention for possessing drugs and threatening to kill an associate.
As part of a rush of planning, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration said it had lined up some sponsors for a victory parade for the U.S. women's soccer team.

display_asset.caption: The oPhone Duo is a tabletop device that can emit scents based on how an iPhone photo is labeled.

summaries.body: Developers are preparing products that let smartphone users send and receive scents. Above, a device that can emit scents based on how a photo is labeled.
Disney World has joined businesses and governments in distancing itself from the Confederate flag: it removed a version of the banner from Epcot's American Adventure.
The outspoken sportscaster Keith Olbermann is leaving ESPN after less than two years hosting his namesake talk show “Olbermann," a statement said.
Pregnant women who seek a change in work duties are sometimes fired or forced into unpaid leave because their doctor’s note was not carefully worded, experts said.
More than 200 Americans have traveled or attempted to travel to Syria to fight for Islamic militants, said James B. Comey, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

display_asset.caption: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India that he was considering taking up yoga during their meeting on Wednesday in Ufa, Russia.

summaries.body: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, known for his skills in judo and other macho sports, said in a meeting with India’s leader that he will embrace yoga as well.
Poverty may be down worldwide, but more than half the world’s population were classified as “low-income” in 2011, meaning they live on $2 to $10 a day, a study said.

display_asset.caption: Children scavenged for goods behind homes as pigs wallowed nearby in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, during a cholera epidemic in 2012.

summaries.body: An inexpensive, little-known cholera vaccine appears to work so well that it can protect entire communities and perhaps head off explosive epidemics, a new study said.
JPMorgan Chase will pay $136 million to settle charges that it used illegal tactics to go after delinquent credit card borrowers, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said.
José Andrés, the Washington-based chef, said he is backing out of a deal to open a restaurant in a Donald Trump hotel in protest over his anti-immigrant comments.
In drought-hit California, Los Angeles announced a plan to increase rates for water, charging heavy users more than residents who use less water.
Russia vetoed a draft resolution in the U.N. Security Council condemning the 1995 Srebrenica massacre as a “crime of genocide.” Above, a memorial site near the town.
A court in Italy sentenced Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister, to three years in jail for bribery, but he will not have to serve his time because of a statute of limitations.
A federal judge threw out a $533 million award that Apple was told in February to pay to a patent owner over iTunes software. The judge ordered a new trial on the damages.
The N.F.L. has agreed to play at least two games a year for 10 years in London at the new stadium for Tottenham Hotspur, a Premier League club, beginning in 2018.
Taco Bell is testing delivery service at 200 stores in California and Texas, becoming the latest fast-food chain to consider expanding into delivery.
Rory McIlroy, the world's top-ranked golfer, said he will not play in next week's British Open after injuring his ankle while playing soccer last week.
Comedy Central renewed "South Park," the cartoon written and directed by Trey Parker and Matt Stone since 1997, for three more seasons through 2019.
United Airlines grounded planes nationwide on Wednesday for about two hours because of what the company said was a computer glitch.
A federal judge upheld the cancellation of the Washington Redskins' federal trademark registrations in a legal and symbolic setback for the N.F.L. team.
A county water district has accused Tom Selleck, the actor, of stealing truckloads of water from a hydrant in drought-racked California, according to court documents.

asset.embed_html: <iframe class="embedly-embed" src="//cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fembed%2F0Sm0b8UtxGU%3Ffeature%3Doembed&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3D0Sm0b8UtxGU&image=https%3A%2F%2Fi.ytimg.com%2Fvi%2F0Sm0b8UtxGU%2Fhqdefault.jpg&key=170aca4a25074a88942b11f27e7ca43f&type=text%2Fhtml&schema=youtube" width="854" height="480" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

summaries.body: Europe's divisions were clear as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece asked for solidarity from the European Parliament and his detractors criticized Greece.
A 24-hour strike by 20,000 London Underground workers is set to begin at 6:30 p.m. on Wednesday and is expected to significantly disrupt travel.
Walt Disney World is removing a Bill Cosby statue from its Hollywood Studios theme park in Florida, a spokeswoman said.
